dt: {bc}of, relating to, or being a grammatical case {dx_def}see {dxt|case:1||3a}{/dx_def} that typically marks a person or thing that possesses someone or something else or the source from which someone or something comes {dx}compare {dxt|possessive||}{/dx}
{bc}expressing a relationship that in some inflected languages is often marked by a genitive case
used especially of English prepositional phrases introduced by {it}of{/it}

et: Middle English, from Latin {it}genetivus, genitivus{/it}, literally, of generation (erroneous translation of Greek {it}genikos{/it} genitive), from {it}genitus{/it}
shortdef: of, relating to, or being a grammatical case that typically marks a person or thing that possesses someone or something else or the source from which someone or something comes
expressing a relationship that in some inflected languages is often marked by a genitive case —used especially of English prepositional phrases introduced by of

dt: {bc}a syntactic construction in English in which possession is marked both by the preposition {it}of{/it} and a noun or pronoun in the possessive case (as in "A friend of Bob's is a friend of mine")

shortdef: a syntactic construction in English in which possession is marked both by the preposition of and a noun or pronoun in the possessive case (as in "A friend of Bob's is a friend of mine") —called also double possessive
